questions.question: What is 'steelmanning'?
options: Articulating your opponent's argument in its strongest possible form before responding
Attacking the weakest version of an argument
Refusing to engage with opposing views
Using metal metaphors in debate
questions.explanation: Steelmanning is the opposite of strawmanning. Instead of weakening your opponent's argument, you strengthen it—articulating their position better than they did, filling gaps, removing ambiguities—then addressing that improved version.
hints: What's the opposite of a 'straw man'?
Why would you help your opponent make their case?

questions.question: According to the chapter, defeating a weak version of an opponent's argument proves you've won the debate.
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes: 'Beating a weak version proves nothing except that your opponent argued poorly. Beating a strong version—the best case that could be made for the other side—proves the position itself has problems. The victory is real.'
hints: What does defeating a strawman actually prove?
Why does the strength of the opposed argument matter?

questions.question: What is the 'principle of charity' in argumentation?
options: Interpreting others' statements in the most reasonable way possible, filling gaps generously
Donating to philosophical causes
Being kind to your opponent regardless of their argument
Avoiding all criticism
questions.explanation: The principle of charity means assuming the most reasonable interpretation when something is ambiguous, filling gaps generously, and giving the benefit of the doubt. It distinguishes stated arguments from intended arguments.
hints: How should you handle ambiguous statements?
What's the alternative—'interpretive hostility'?

questions.question: What is the 'Ideological Turing Test' mentioned in the chapter?
options: Articulating your opponent's position so well that a neutral observer can't tell if you believe it
A computer program that generates arguments
A test for logical fallacies
A formal debate scoring system
questions.explanation: Bryan Caplan's Ideological Turing Test asks: can you articulate your opponent's position well enough that a neutral observer couldn't tell whether you believe it? If your summary is obviously hostile, you haven't done the intellectual work.
hints: What would passing this test prove?
How can you tell if your summary is hostile?

questions.question: Based on the chapter's steelmanning process, what should you do first?
questions.scenario: A family member shares a political view you strongly disagree with. You want to engage productively rather than just argue.
options: Really listen, articulate their position back to them, then strengthen it before responding
Immediately explain why they're wrong with your best arguments
Find the weakest point in what they said and attack it
Change the subject to avoid conflict
questions.explanation: The chapter outlines a process: (1) Really listen, (2) Articulate their position back to check understanding, (3) Strengthen the argument by filling gaps, then (4) Respond to the steelmanned version. 'Ninety seconds of steelmanning saves ninety minutes of talking past each other.'
hints: What are the steps in the steelmanning process?
What should happen before you critique?

questions.question: Match each reason for steelmanning with its benefit:

pairs.left: If you defeat the strongest version, you've proven something real
Looking for ways you might be wrong

questions.explanation: The chapter gives three reasons: (1) defeating the strongest version proves the position itself is flawed, (2) understanding opponents builds ethos and earns respect, (3) actively seeking flaws in your own reasoning protects against self-deception.
hints: What happens when you only beat a weak argument?
How does steelmanning relate to intellectual honesty?

questions.question: According to Daniel Dennett's rules quoted in the chapter, what should you do before criticizing?
options: Re-express your target's position so clearly that they say 'Thanks, I wish I'd thought of putting it that way'
Find their weakest point immediately
Ignore their strongest arguments
Focus only on what you disagree with
questions.explanation: Dennett's first rule: 'You should attempt to re-express your target's position so clearly, vividly, and fairly that your target says, "Thanks, I wish I'd thought of putting it that way."' Only then are you prepared to criticize.
hints: What standard does Dennett set for understanding opponents?
How do you know you've understood well enough?

questions.question: According to the chapter, steelmanning means you must agree with your opponent's conclusion.
questions.explanation: Steelmanning doesn't require agreement—it requires understanding. You articulate the strongest version of their argument, then respond to that version. You may still disagree, but your disagreement will be with their actual position, not a caricature.
hints: What's the difference between understanding and agreeing?
Can you steelman something you ultimately reject?

questions.question: What does the chapter say about people who only engage with weak versions of opposing arguments?
options: They may be signaling tribal loyalty rather than seeking truth
They are always acting in bad faith
They have superior debate skills
They are more efficient debaters
questions.explanation: The chapter notes that attacking strawmen often signals tribal loyalty—showing your side you're on their team—rather than genuine truth-seeking. This may win social approval but doesn't advance understanding.
hints: What social function might strawmanning serve?
What's the difference between truth-seeking and signaling?

questions.question: According to the chapter, what happens when you successfully steelman an opponent?
options: They're more likely to listen to your response because you've shown you understand them
They immediately agree with you
The debate ends
You lose the argument
questions.explanation: The chapter explains that demonstrating understanding earns goodwill: 'When you've shown you can argue their side as well as they can, they know you're not dismissing them out of ignorance. That makes them more willing to consider your actual response.'
hints: How does understanding affect the other person's receptivity?
Why does showing you've listened matter?
